segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: Then the Buddha, picking up a little bit of dirt under his fingernail, addressed the mendicants:

segments.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yo cāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito yā cāyaṃ mahāpathavī”ti?
segments.en: Which is more: the little bit of dirt under my fingernail, or this great earth?”
“Sir, the great earth is far more.

segments.pli: Appamattakoyaṃ bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito.
segments.en: The little bit of dirt under your fingernail is tiny.

segments.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti upanidhimpi na upeti kalabhāgampi na upeti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito”ti.
segments.en: Compared to the great earth, it can’t be reckoned or compared, it’s not even a fraction.”

segments.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appakā te sattā ye manussesu paccājāyanti;
segments.en: “In the same way the sentient beings reborn as humans are few,

segments.pli: atha kho eteyeva bahutarā sattā ye aññatra manussehi paccājāyanti.
segments.en: while those not reborn as humans are many.
So you should train like this:

suttaplex.blurb: As the dirt in a fingernail is smaller than the great earth, the beings reborn as humans are few.
